review.title: Corpus analysis without prior linguistic knowledge - unsupervised mining of phrases and subphrase structure
review.abstract: When looking at the structure of natural language, "phrases" and "words" are central notions. We consider the problem of identifying such "meaningful subparts" of language of any length and underlying composition principles in a completely corpus-based and language-independent way without using any kind of prior linguistic knowledge. Unsupervised methods for identifying "phrases", mining subphrase structure and finding words in a fully automated way are described. This can be considered as a step towards automatically computing a "general dictionary and grammar of the corpus". We hope that in the long run variants of our approach turn out to be useful for other kind of sequence data as well, such as, e.g., speech, genom sequences, or music annotation. Even if we are not primarily interested in immediate applications, results obtained for a variety of languages show that our methods are interesting for many practical tasks in text mining, terminology extraction and lexicography, search engine technology, and related fields.

metadata.title: Corpus analysis without prior linguistic knowledge - unsupervised mining of phrases and subphrase structure

sections.heading: 2 Phrase model - intuitions and motivation
sections.text: As a starting point, we see the idea of a "phrase." However, if we want to recognize the "phrases" in a way that we need as a starting point, we need to make some primitive assumptions about how "meaningful phrases" are recognized and distinguished from them. In our view, we should use these phrases in parallel to recognize and link the structure of natural language. Our main motivation lies in psycholinguistics.

sections.heading: 3 Computing phrases and function words
sections.text: Following the considerations of the previous section, we will first consider the problem of calculating the phrases and functional words of a corpus. In the first section, we will develop an algorithm for solving this problem. We will then present the results obtained for different languages and corpora.

sections.heading: 4 Computing subphrase structure and content words
sections.text: In this section, we will further analyze the structure of phrases. As a side effect, we will get a method to find substantive words (non-functional words) of the corpus.

sections.heading: 4.1 Algorithmic principles
sections.text: In a first step, we explain how to easily generate the components of the phrases in P (C), which we call subphrases. In a second step, we structure the resulting subphrases in a hierarchical manner, in which we obtain a form of decomposition. In a third step, we structure the resulting subphrases in a hierarchical manner, in which we obtain a form of decomposition. sections.heading: 4.2 Results for distinct languages and corpora
sections.text: To illustrate, in Figure 4 we present a decomposition tree and the parallel core decomposition tree for the German phrase proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the RatesEmpty nodes in the nuclear decomposition tree are caused by phrases that become empty when the functional word margins are removed. The functional scheme for the phrase has the form | den | fu "r eine | des | and the |. Nuclear subphrase cores that are preserved are u" ber, Proposal, Directive, European, Parliament, and Council.The results for the phrase decomposition in the European languages are similar. As mentioned above, the functional scheme for a phrase is unique in almost every case, even if there are several decomposition trees. This shows that the difference between different decomposition forms is mainly a problem of different orders in which the (sub-) phrases are decomposed, not a problem of the different final decomposition parts.

sections.heading: 5 Applications
sections.text: In this section we will consider a selection of possible applications of the above methods. In any case, it will be shown that the automated calculation of phrases and subphrases of a corpus and the bidirectional structure of the index structure used offer interesting possibilities to approach known problems in new ways.

sections.heading: 5.3 Automated query expansion for search engines and free context size answer browsing
sections.text: It is not easy to estimate in advance the number of replies to a query. If the query is too specific, the number of replies may be small or empty, in other cases the amount of replies becomes extremely large and a manual inspection is not possible. To support users, search engines on the Internet often present a selection of possible right extensions to an unspecific string. For example, if you type "John" in the search window of English Wikipedia, some extensions such as "John McCain," "John Lennon" and others (see above) are used to automatically produce the technology shown above interesting expansions. A given short query is treated only as a kernel within the meaning of Section 5.2. Simply using Wikipedia 3 "kernel expansion" of the above method, interesting right and left expansions are found for a query.

sections.heading: Appendix A
sections.text: We present the top segments of terminological expressions obtained for some diseases of Alzheimer's disease using the method described in Section 5.2. No filtering or cleaning steps were applied to improve the list. We consider the problem of identifying such “meaningful subparts” of language of any length and underlying composition principles in a completely corpus-based and language-independent way without using any kind of prior linguistic knowledge. Unsupervised methods for identifying “phrases”, mining subphrase structure and finding words in a fully automated way are described. This can be considered as a step towards automatically computing a “general dictionary and grammar of the corpus”. We hope that in the long run variants of our approach turn out to be useful for other kind of sequence data as well, such as, e.g., speech, genom sequences, or music annotation. Even if we are not primarily interested in immediate applications, results obtained for a variety of languages show that our methods are interesting for many practical tasks in text mining, terminology extraction and lexicography, search engine technology, and related fields.
